Problem Statements: A duplicate active container/advice record exists (example: LION_CITY_07), causing uniqueness conflicts on creation. Likely caused by replication job overlap or an unexpired legacy record and lack of enforced unique-active protection in practice.
Solution: Validate the active advice to determine whether it is a legitimate current record or a legacy duplicate. For legacy records, expire the older entry (set effective_end_datetime), re-sync caches, and re-attempt creation. For genuine conflicts, instruct the user to choose a unique identifier or merge manually. Run a controlled de-dup job, verify row counts, and enforce a unique-active database constraint or pre-create API validation to prevent future duplicates. Notify Product Ops, EDI/API and SRE teams and monitor after remediation.
SOP: If duplicates exist, expire older record and re-sync cache

Problem Statements: Two active container/advice rows exist for the same identifier (e.g., LION_CITY_07). The system enforces a single active advice per container; duplicate active rows (caused by replication overlap / legacy data) block creation or updates and cause user-facing conflicts.
Solution: Expire the older/legacy active record so only the correct advice remains active, re-sync caches and APIs, then re-attempt the create/update. Prevent recurrence by enforcing a unique-active constraint at the database layer, run a de-duplication job to remove any remaining duplicates, fix the replication job overlap that caused the issue, and notify Product Ops/CS. Escalate to EDI/API or SRE if cache/replication problems persist.
SOP: If duplicates exist, expire older record and re-sync cache

Problem Statements: Duplicate active container records exist (two active rows for same container/advice), preventing creation or causing ambiguous active advice due to the system's unique-active constraint.
Solution: Expire the older duplicate record (soft-deprecate by setting effective_end_datetime) after taking a backup, then re-sync the database and cache so the system state matches the canonical record. Run a de-duplication job and enforce/repair a unique-active index to prevent recurrence. Notify Product Ops/EDI/SRE, re-attempt the operation, and monitor for further duplicates.
SOP: If duplicates exist, expire older record and re-sync cache

Solution: Consolidate the duplicate container rows by choosing a canonical record (recommended: container_id 21), update all referencing tables to point to it, archive and remove the duplicate row in a controlled transaction after taking a backup, then enforce a database uniqueness constraint on container.cntr_no and switch snapshot inserts to atomic upserts. Improve tracing/logging for snapshot operations and notify downstream consumers so they refresh caches and confirm the issue is resolved.

If that fails, coordinate with DB/Platform to choose the authoritative row, reassign foreign-keyed references to it, and delete the orphaned row inside a transaction. Finally, invalidate caches/republish the canonical state, capture before/after evidence, and implement preventive measures (source-message idempotency keys or a uniqueness constraint and monitoring) to avoid recurrence.
